Thanksgiving was a blow out traffic day. On Wednesday, February 18, Akamai was honored to host a presentation and discussion with Deborah Hughes, President and CEO of Brookview House, Inc. Deborah was presented with the 2014 Be the Change Award by the Massachusetts Conference for Women.  Brookview House is an independent, non-profit organization founded in 1990, whose innovative idea was that offering housing coupled with support services for both moms and kids would get families out of the revolving door of homelessness. Deborah has served as the Executive Director at Brookview House since 1993.

Teaching life skills to the children are an important part of the services that Brookview House provides.  In line with those services, Brookview House runs a Girls Who Code club.  Prior to Deborah’s presentation, members of the Akamai Women’s Forum and the newly formed Akamai African American Employee Group are excited to be hosting these girls for a day of activities learning about how the Internet works. Brookview House visits Akamai HQ

We are excited about International Women's Day 2014! This is a holiday celebrated around the world, with a history going back for over 100 years. In the United States, it’s part of a larger celebration of March as Women's History Month. This year's theme is "Inspiring Change" - for greater awareness of women’s equality, for more women in senior leadership roles, and for more women in science, engineering, and technology. Various Akamai events in different geographies were scheduled for Thursday March 6th and Friday March 7th, many featuring Akamai executives and other local leaders as speakers. One of the biggest concerns in front-end web optimization is getting pixels in front of the user as quickly as possible. At this Meetup, we're going to take a closer look at how the browser renders images on the page (the "render chain"), how it relates to a standard waterfall chart, and what you can do to make sure that the browser can draw pages as quickly as possible.

You're invited to attend this Meetup in Cambridge on Tuesday, August 13, at 6:30pm, led by Akamai's Matt Ringel and Joseph Morrissey. To RSVP, visit: http://bit.ly/15rhQ18 Matt Ringel and Joseph Morrissey - The Render Chain and You (at Akamai) -  Boston Web Performance Gr You're invited to attend this Meetup in Cambridge on Tuesday, August 13, at 6:30pm, led by Akamai's Matt Ringel and Joseph Morrissey. http://bit.ly/15rhQ18

El rápido crecimiento del mercado  de telecomunicaciones  y las oportunidades de encontrar talento calificado en Costa Rica motivó a la firma estadounidense Akamai Technologies a iniciar operaciones en el país. Akamai significa inteligencia en hawaiano y es el nombre de la firma que crearon Daniel Lewin y Tom Leighton,  en ese momento estudiante y profesor del MIT, con el dinero que obtuvieron cuando su propuesta de utilizar matemáticas aplicadas para solucionar problemas de congestión en Internet ganó un concurso para emprendedores. El premio les permitió  impulsar su empresa que hoy es una de las lideres en su campo.  Akamai es un ejemplo más de la prosperidad compartida que permite el libre comercio. 

Más información en La República:
